(b) The notice of appeal shall be addressed to the board of commissioners and shall specify the subject matter of the appeal, the date of any original and amended application or requests, the date of the adverse decision (or receipt of notice), the basis of the appeal, the action requested of the board of commissioners, and the name and address of the applicant. (c) The clerk shall place the appeal on the agenda of the next regular board of commissioners meeting occurring not less than five days nor more than 30 days after receipt of the application for board action. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 20) Sec. 10-52. - Council determines appeal procedure. When an appeal is placed on the agenda, the board of commissioners may take either of the following actions: (1) Set a hearing date and instruct the county clerk/treasurer to give such notice of hearing as may be required by law. (2) Appoint a hearing officer and fix the time and place for hearing. The hearing officer may or may not be a county employee and may be appointed for an extended period of time. The clerk shall assume responsibility for such publication of notice of the hearing as may be required by law. If a hearing officer is appointed, the hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set out in this article. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 21) Sec. 10-53. - Board hearing. Whenever the county clerk/treasurer has scheduled an appeal before the board of commissioners, at the time and date set, the board of commissioners shall receive all relevant testimony and evidence from the permittee, from interested parties, and from county staff. The board of commissioners may sustain, overrule or modify the action complained of. The action of the board of commissioners shall be final. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 22) Sec. 10-54. - Powers of hearing officer. The hearing officer appointed pursuant to the procedure set out in this article may receive and rule on admissibility of evidence, hear testimony under oath, and call witnesses as he may deem advisable with respect to the conduct of the hearing. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 23) Sec. 10-55. - Rules of evidence inapplicable. In hearings conducted under this article, the board of commissioners and the hearing officer shall not be bound by the traditional rules of evidence. Rules of evidence as applied in an administrative hearing shall apply. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 24) Sec. 10-56. - Hearing officer report. (a) The hearing officer shall, within a reasonable time not to exceed 30 days from the date a hearing under this article is terminated, submit a written report to the board of commissioners. Such report shall contain a brief summary of the evidence considered and state findings, conclusions and recommendations. All such reports shall be filed with the county clerk/treasurer and shall be considered public records. A copy of such report shall be forwarded by certified mail to the permittee/applicant the same day it is filed with the county clerk/treasurer, with additional copies furnished the county administrator and sheriff. (b) The county clerk/treasurer shall place the hearing officer's report on the agenda of the next regular board meeting after the report is filed and shall notify the permittee/appellant of the date of such meeting at least ten days prior to the meeting unless the permittee/appellant stipulates to a shorter notice period. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 25) Sec. 10-57. - Action by board of commissioners. The board of commissioners may adopt or reject a hearing officer's decision in its entirety or may modify the proposed recommendation. If the board of commissioners does not adopt the hearing officer's recommendation, it may: (1) Refer the matter to the same or another hearing officer for a completely new hearing or for the taking of additional evidence on specific points; in either of such cases, the hearing officer shall proceed as provided in this section; or (2) Decide the case upon a review of the entire record before the hearing officer with or without taking additional evidence. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 26) Sec. 10-58. - Unlawful operation declared nuisance. Any adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this article shall be declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The county may, in addition to or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action under this article, commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings for abatement, removal or enjoinment in the manner provided by law. It shall take such other steps and shall apply to such courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such adult entertainment establishment contrary to the provisions of this article. In addition, violation of the provisions of this article shall be per se grounds for suspension or revocation of a license granted under this article. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 28) Sec. 10-59. - Cleaning of licensed premises. Each premises licensed under this article shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be cleaned at least once daily and more frequently when necessary. This activity shall be supervised by the person in charge of the licensed premises. There shall be provided adequate facilities, equipment and supplies on the licensed premises to meet this requirement, and adequate ventilation and illumination shall be provided to permit thorough, complete cleaning of the entire licensed premises. Trash and garbage shall not be permitted to accumulate or to become a nuisance on or in the immediate vicinity of the licensed premises but shall be disposed of daily or as often as collection permits. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 29) Sec. 10-60. - Self-inspection of licensed premises. The licensee of premises licensed under this article or his designated representative shall make sanitary inspections of the licensed premises at least once a month and shall record his findings on a form supplied by the licensing officer. Each licensed premises shall post and maintain in a readily accessible place a schedule for maintaining the sanitation of the premises. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 30) Sec. 10-61. - Sealing for unsanitary or unsafe conditions. A premises licensed under this article may be sealed by order of the licensing officer on his finding of a violation of this article resulting in an unsanitary or unsafe condition. Prior to sealing, the licensing officer shall serve on the licensee, by personal service on him or by posting in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises, a notice of the violation and an order to correct it within 24 hours after service. If the violation is not so corrected, the licensing officer may physically seal that portion of the licensed premises causing the violation and order the discontinuance of use until the violation has been corrected and the seal removed by the licensing officer. The licensing officer shall affix to the sealed premises a conspicuous sign labeled "Unclean" or "Unsafe," as the case may be. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 31) Sec. 10-62. - Abatement as sanitary nuisance. A licensed premises may be abated as a sanitary nuisance. (Ord. of 2-13-1996, § 32) Sec. 10-63. - Enforcement and administration. The county planning director shall have enforcement and administrative responsibilities, in addition to those officers previously granted enforcement and administrative responsibilities, with respect to this article. (Res. of 8-25-1998)

div.head: Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 42. State Law reference— Dogfighting, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; sale of dog meat for human consumption prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-160; fish, O.C.G.A. § 27-4-30 et seq.; wild animals, O.C.G.A. § 27-5-4 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; animal bites, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4; inoculation of dogs and cats against rabies, rabies inoculation tags, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq.; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to run at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7; authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abandon means the act of placing an animal on public property or within a public building, unattended or uncared for, or on or within the private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian or tenant of the private property. An animal shall also be considered abandoned when it has been unattended and without adequate food or water for a period in excess of 36 continuous hours regardless of where such animal may be found or kept. Adequate food means sufficient quantity of non-contaminated and nutritionally healthy sustenance that is sufficient to prevent starvation, malnutrition, or risk to the animal's health. Garbage, spoiled, rancid, or contaminated food is not adequate food. Adequate water means sufficient quantity of potable water. Animal control facility means and includes any vehicle, building, structure, pasture, paddock, pond, impoundment area or premises where any animal is kept or housed by the animal control unit for the purpose of impounding or harboring stray, homeless, abandoned, unwanted, neglected or abused animals. Animal control officer means an employee of the county duly empowered under the legal authority of the county to enforce the rules and regulations of this article. Dogs running at-large means any dog not under immediate control, not on a leash, not at heel, not beside a competent person, not in a vehicle driven or parked, or not confined within the property limits of his owner. Hunting, tracking dogs, and dogs used for agriculture are under the control of the owner when hunting or used with the landowner's permission. Domestic animal means an animal that, through long association with humans, has been adapted to human living conditions. Impoundment means the act of taking physical possession and control of an animal by an animal control officer or other officer empowered to act by law and transporting it to the animal control facility. Owner means any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, and/or other legal entity, who or which owns, possesses, harbors, keeps, feeds, maintains, or knowingly causes or knowingly permits an animal to be harbored or kept, or has an animal in his care, or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, any adult at whose residence a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is kept or found shall be presumed to be an owner of such dog and shall have the burden of rebutting such presumption. If an animal has more than one owner, any one of such owners may be prosecuted for violations whether or not any other owners are also prosecuted. Provocation means committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner or possessor of the animal, or teasing, tormenting, or abusing the animal or committing or attempting to commit a crime against a person. Vicious dog means as defined in O.C.G.A. Title 4, Chapter 8. Georgia Rabies Control Law requires all owned dogs be vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian using approved vaccines (O.C.G.A. 31-19). (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Secs. 14-2—14-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DUTIES, POWERS AND PROHIBITIONS RELATING TO CONTROL OF ANIMALS
Sec. 14-31. - Restraint, running at large prohibited; duty of owner or custodian. (a) It shall be unlawful for any owner or possessor of any dog to fail to keep the dog under restraint or control as provided for in this section for dogs covered in subsequent sections. (b) A dog is considered not under restraint or control when it is running at large off the owner's property whether wearing a collar and tag or not. Reasonable care and precautions shall be taken to prevent the dog from leaving the real property limits of its owner, possessor, or custodian. (c) Dogs found running at-large or in violation of this section may be immediately impounded by officers of the animal control unit or any police officer. The officers may pursue the dog onto private property to effect capture of such dog. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-32. - Abandoned animals. It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly abandon or to aid in the abandonment of any animal. An animal relinquished through written agreement with animal control, licensed rescue group, licensed shelter, licensed veterinarians, individual, or other entity shall not be deemed abandoned but shall be considered relinquished to the entity. Any person violating any provision of section 14-32 may upon conviction be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or 30 days in jail. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-33. - Transient dogs and cats. Any dog or cat shipped or transported through the county or entering the county only for the purpose of a temporary stay, when such stay shall not exceed 15 days, shall be exempt from collar and tag sections of this article. However, all other provisions of this article are applicable to such transient animals. Sec. 14-34. - Public nuisance animal. (a) A public nuisance animal shall mean and include any animal that: (1) Is repeatedly found at-large; (2) Damages the property of anyone other than the owner; (3) Is vicious; (4) Attacks without provocation; or (5) Chases vehicles, bicycles, or people outside of the owner's property. (b) Any such public nuisance animal may be impounded and the owner or possessor charged for a violation of this article. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-35. - Disposition of impounded animals. (a) Any animal, seized or impounded by an animal control officer, or any officer empowered to act by law may be temporarily detained at a local animal control facility and/or detained at the animal shelter facility the county is currently in contract with. Custody of seized animals will be transferred from the county to the animal shelter facility the county is currently in contract with upon release of the animal to that animal shelter. (b) For any animal that is impounded for law enforcement purposes, at the owner's request and expense, such impoundment may be at a veterinary or licensed kennel of the owner's choosing provided that the owner cannot cause the animal to be released from the boarding facility without the approval of the prosecuting officer or agent. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-36. - Tags. It shall be the duty of each dog owner or possessor to provide a collar with identification tag and current rabies vacation attached for each dog listing the owners name and phone number within 15 days of the owner taking possession of the dog. Collar shall be on the animal at all times when the animal is not under the immediate control of the owner or possessor of the animal. Dogs without tags may be considered in violation of section 14-31. Animals participating in organized or controlled competitions are exempt from this subsection only for the duration of the competition. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-37. - Interference with animal control officers. It shall be unlawful to interfere with any animal control officer or other officer empowered to act by law, or to take or attempt to take any animal from the county vehicle used to transport the animal, or to take or attempt to take any animal from the animal control facility, or by any other method which would block or hinder any officer referred to in this section from performing his duties. It shall also be unlawful for any person to relocate, alter, or interfere with the operation of any device, trap, equipment or item belonging to the County of Hart's animal control unit. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-38. - Duty of animal owners to be responsible owners. It shall be the duty of every owner or custodian of any animal to exercise reasonable care and take all necessary steps and precautions to protect other people, property, and animals from injuries or damage which might result from their animal's behavior. If the owner or custodian of any animal is a minor, the parent or guardian of such minor shall be responsible to ensure compliance with all provisions of this article. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-39. - Removal of feral dog packs. The animal control officer has the right to immediately seize and remove all or parts of any feral dog pack for public safety and public health concerns, including rabies, other zoonotic disease epidemics, and certain animal-to-animal diseases as identified by the animal control officer. The method of removal may be in the form of trapping or extermination that shall be designed to be as humane as possible under the circumstances as allowed by O.C.G.A. 16-12-4(f)(2). (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-40. - Prohibition on feeding stray and feral animals. (a) Feral and stray animals constitute public safety, health, and environmental risks to domesticated animals, wildlife, and persons. It is a violation of this section for any person to feed or harbor feral or stray animals. (b) Exceptions: A person may feed or harbor a feral or stray animal if there is a good faith effort to humanely capture the animal for the purpose of surrender to the animal control unit within 72 hours of capture. (Ord. of 7-9-2013) Sec. 14-41. - Penalties. Any person violating any provision of this article, with the exception of section 14-32, shall be first issued a warning (first offense). Subsequent offenses of any provision of this article for failure to comply with any of its requirements shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-13, and in addition may be liable to pay all costs and expenses involved in such case. (Ord. of 7-9-2013)

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 42; land development standards, ch. 46; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 50; planning, ch. 62; roads and bridges, ch. 66; road names and house numbers, § 66-66 et seq.; signs, ch. 70; solid waste, ch. 74. State Law reference— Water Well Standards Act of 1985, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-120; access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; ordinances relating to repair, closing and demolition of dwellings unfit for human habitation or buildings or structures that imperil health, safety or morals, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; authority to demolish structures where drug crimes are committed, authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; county or municipal ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9 et seq.; water efficiency requirements, construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; fire escapes in buildings, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Self-inspection exemption. The board of commissioners, pursuant to 1996 Ga. Laws, page 1632, exempts the county from the alternative inspection procedure as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d). (Res. of 5-14-1996) Secs. 18-2—18-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BUILDING PERMITS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26.
Sec. 18-31. - Required. (a) No new construction may be initiated within the county for any building of any type without a building permit. (b) No construction that involves the renovation of or addition to any existing building may be commenced without a building permit. In addition, a building permit will be required prior to alteration of the existing roofline, existing building foundation or footprint, or the existing general physical character of the structure. (c) As used herein, the term "construction" includes building, erection, placement, anchoring or otherwise siting any building, whether pre-fabricated, manufactured off site, or otherwise. (d) No public utility shall connect service at any site within the county without proof of a county building permit. (e) Building permits will not be issued without proof of a sanitation permit for the premises. (f) A building permit shall become invalid unless the work authorized by it shall have been commenced within 90 days after its date of issue, or if the work authorized by the permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of six months or more. Commencement of construction means erection of temporary forms, pouring of slabs or footings, installation of piers or columns, or the actual start of a building or altering of a structure either temporary or permanent. Commencement for commercial, industrial, or agricultural construction projects shall include the physical moving of dirt. Hardship cases may be considered for extension by the board of commissioners. (g) A building permit is required for planned building or renovations of greater than $2,500.00. (Ord. of 12-30-1991; Ord. of 7-13-1992; Ord. of 11-11-1997, § 1; Ord. of 12-11-2001; Amend. of 2-10-2004; Ord. of 6-23-2015(1)) Sec. 18-32. - Application. A building permit may be obtained by the property owner at the county administrative office. (Ord. of 11-11-1997, § 2; Ord. of 12-11-2001) Sec. 18-33. - Exemptions. (a) The requirements of section 18-31 do not apply when the planned building or renovation does not add any value greater than $1,500.00 to the value of the existing property. It is not the intent of this article to require a building permit for routine maintenance or repairs, as long as the routine maintenance or repairs utilize the same or substantially similar replacement materials as used in the existing structure. (b) No building permit shall be required for the replacement of plumbing, wiring or paint of the existing structure. (c) No building permit shall be required for mobile homes or manufactured housing, providing that the same are permitted under other provisions of this Code. (Ord. of 11-11-1997, § 3; Ord. of 12-11-2001) Sec. 18-34. - Enforcement. (a) Building permits issued under this article shall be prominently displayed at the building site, and visible from the nearest road. (b) All law enforcement agencies, officers and officials of the county or any enforcement agency or officer of the state is authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this article. The county code enforcement officer is responsible for investigating and ensuring compliance with this article. (c) Any person violating this article shall be tried before the county magistrate court. Upon conviction, a violation of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Ord. of 11-11-1997, § 4; Res. of 8-25-1998; Ord. of 12-11-2001) Secs. 18-35—18-65. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FLOW RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3.
Sec. 18-66. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel. (Ord. of 6-25-1991, § 1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 18-67. - Compliance with plumbing code required—Residential buildings. No construction may be initiated within the county for any residential building of any type that does not comply with the following requirements of the state plumbing code, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3: (1) Employs a gravity tank type, flushometer valve, or flushometer tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; (2) Employs a showerhead that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 1.0 gallon of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (Ord. of 6-25-1991, § 2) Sec. 18-68. - Same—Commercial buildings. There shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the county for any commercial building of any type that does not meet the requirements of the requirements of the state plumbing code, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-2, as stated in section 18-67. (Ord. of 6-25-1991, § 3) Sec. 18-69. - Applicability. The requirements of section 18-67 shall apply to any residential construction initiated after April 1, 1992, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets and/or showers. (Ord. of 6-25-1991, § 4) Sec. 18-70. - Exemptions. (a) New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of this article when: (1) The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewerage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; (2) When such plumbing or sewerage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this article were installed; (3) Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or (4) Units to be installed are: a. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; b. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or c. Toilets for juveniles. (b) The owner of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (a)(2), (3) or (4) of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the county courthouse, board of commissioners. A fee specified in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (Ord. of 6-25-1991, § 5) Sec. 18-71. - Enforcement. (a) This article shall be enforced by the sheriff's department, the county public works director or the county planning director. (b) Any person violating this article shall be tried before the county magistrate court. Upon conviction, a violation of this article may be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Ord. of 6-25-1991, § 6) Secs. 18-72—18-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - POULTRY HOUSE CONSTRUCTION[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— Ord. of 2-13-2018, §§ 1—8, amended Art. IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. IV, §§ 18-91—18-99, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of 6-23-2015(2).
Sec. 18-91. - Definitions. Except as otherwise provided herein, all words shall have their customary dictionary meaning. The present tense includes the future tense. The singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular. The word "person" includes a firm, corporation, association, organization, trust or partnership. The word "lot" includes "plot" or "parcel." The word "building" includes "structure." The word "shall" is always mandatory. The word "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied." The term "erected" shall be deemed also to include "constructed," "reconstructed," "altered," "placed," or "moved." The word "land use" and "use of land" shall be deemed also to include "building use" and "use of buildings." The word "adjacent" means "nearby" and not necessarily "contiguous." Agriculture or agricultural means a parcel used primarily for soil-dependent cultivation of agricultural crop production, the raising of livestock or poultry, growth of a field, or forestry. Applicant means any person who applies for a building permit, and any attorney or other person representing or acting on behalf of a person who applies for a building permit. Board of commissioners means Hart County Board of Commissioners. Buffer area means a continuous landscaped or naturalized area used to separate and partially obstruct the view of a poultry operation from adjacent or contiguous development. Building means any structure, either permanent or temporary, above or below ground having roof or other covering, designed, built or used as a shelter or enclosure for persons, animals, or property of any kind. Nonconforming means any lawfully existing building or structure which does not conform to these ordinances governing the type, bulk, location, height or size of buildings or structures permitted prior to the adoption of this article but which is in full compliance with all applicable federal, state and local laws, rules and ordinances, and for which all required federal, state and local permits have been issued. Principal use means the primary purpose for which land or a building is used. Residential means an enclosure containing sleeping, kitchen, and bathroom facilities designed for and used or held ready for use as a permanent residence by one family. Right-of-way means that area, distinguished from an easement, for the present or future use of roads, streets, highways and utilities, together with its drainage facilities and other supporting uses and structures. Screening means a method where a view of one site is shielded, concealed, or hidden from another site. Screening techniques include berms, densely planted vegetation, natural vegetation or other features. Screening must provide a visual and acoustical barrier that is of such nature and density that it provides year-round maximum shielding, concealment or hiding from the ground to a height of at least eight feet or from view from the normal level of a first story window on an abutting lot. Setback (from buildings) means the minimum horizontal distance between the lot or property line and the nearest front, side or rear line of the building, including terraces or any covered projections but excluding steps. Street means a public or private thoroughfare which affords the principal means of ingress and egress to abutting property. Structure means anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on or in the ground, or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. (Ord. of 2-13-2018) Sec. 18-92. - Separation between agricultural and residential uses. Adequate separation must be provided between agricultural structures or operations, as enumerated in this section, and neighboring residences for any new construction, in accordance with the provisions of this section. The location of the existing residential structure or agricultural structure operation shall be determined as of the date a building permit has been issued. (1) Separation required for new or expanded operations construction. Any active poultry house when constructed shall be located no closer than 200 feet measured in a straight line from the nearest point of any property line in the front or sides of the houses. The rear exhaust end must be at least 300 feet from the property line unless an inhabitable residential dwelling is located inline with the rear of the poultry house on an adjacent property. The rear exhaust end must also be 600 feet from an adjacent property inhabitable residential dwelling as measured directly inline behind the poultry house. This does not include dwellings on the property on which the poultry house is being constructed. (2) Separation from existing uses. When a new residence is to be constructed on a neighboring property in proximity to any existing agricultural structure or operation for which separation is required by this section, but the existing structure or operation does not comply with such required distance, the new residence shall be separated from such structure or operation as follows. The new residence shall be located no closer than 300 feet measured in a straight line from the nearest point of the new residential structure to the nearest point of any existing poultry house structure. (3) Waiver for adjacent uses. When a non-agricultural use is proposed for property abutting existing poultry house or will be located within the required minimum setbacks, the developer or property owner shall sign a waiver which will indicate that the applicant understands that there is an ongoing agricultural land use adjacent to the subject property which could produce odors, noise, dust, and other effects which may not be compatible with the applicant's development. Nevertheless, understanding the effects of agricultural operations and uses on adjacent land, the applicant agrees, by executing the waiver, to waive any objection to those effects and understands that his permit is issued and processing in reliance on his agreement not to bring any action against adjacent land owners, whose property is agricultural and or an agricultural operation, or any local government, asserting that the adjacent agricultural operations or uses of agricultural land constitutes a nuisance; provided that said existing agricultural use is operated in conformance with this Article and with all applicable local, state, and federal regulations. Any such notice or acknowledgement provided to or executed by a land owner adjoining an existing agricultural use or within the required minimum setbacks for said use shall be public record. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 1) Sec. 18-93. - Existing non-conforming poultry facilities. Existing facilities at the time this article is adopted, which do not meet the requirements specified herein for new or expanded operations shall be "grandfathered" in as nonconforming for the purposes of this article. Such operations shall not have to comply with location and setback restrictions for existing structures/facilities, provided they are in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations for water and air quality. (1) Change of ownership. In the event that a current operation poultry farm changes ownership for any reason, the existing poultry structures/facilities on these farms shall be "grandfathered" in as nonconforming for the purposes of this article. Such operations shall not have to comply with location and setback restrictions for existing structures/facilities, provided they are in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations for water and air quality. (2) Inactive farms. Existing poultry farms structures/facilities that have been in an inactive state for less than five years shall also be "grandfathered" in as nonconforming for the purposes of this article. Such operations shall not have to comply with location and setback restrictions for existing structures/facilities, provided they are in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations for water and air quality. (3) Rebuilding of existing poultry farms structures/facilities shall also be "grandfathered" in as nonconforming for the purposes of this article but only if the building is built on the same existing building footprint. Such operations shall not have to comply with location and setback restrictions for existing structures/facilities, provided they are in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations for water and air quality. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 2) Sec. 18-94. - Stackhouses and poultry disposal methods. Manure stackhouses and poultry disposal methods shall be located no closer than 100 feet measured in a straight line from the nearest point of any property line in the front, rear, or sides of the stack house. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 3) Sec. 18-95. - Additional setback requirements. In addition to the other setbacks set forth in this article, no commercial poultry house shall be constructed where the any part of the poultry house is 1,000 feet or less from any building that is regularly used as a government building, school, hospital, church, other house of worship, senior center, nursing home, retirement home, restaurant, or public community center provided, however, that this requirement may be waived by the owner of the property (or their authorized agents) on which such an establishment is located. If more than one person owns or has any ownership interest of record of the property where such an establishment is located, then the consent of all owners shall be required. In addition to the other setbacks set forth in this article, no commercial poultry house shall be constructed where any part of the poultry house is 1,000 feet or less from the property line of any public park, public recreational area, or Corps of Engineers Lake Hartwell, provided, however, that this requirement may be waived by the owner of the property (or their authorized agents) on which such an establishment is located. If more than one person owns or has any ownership interest of record of the property where such an establishment is located, then the consent of all owners shall be required. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 4) Sec. 18-96. - Waivers. In order to be effective under this chapter, any and all waivers or consents required by this chapter must be in writing, signed by the parties from whom such waivers or consents must be obtained, and such waivers or consents must be obtained before construction of the commercial poultry house commences. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 5) Sec. 18-97. - Truck routing. Proposed poultry operations must include the truck routing plan to include the most direct truck route from a state highway to the closest county road to the farm. Proposed truck routing from the state highway system must be approved by the GA DOT prior to the issuance of a county building permit. Driveway access to the county road must also be approved by the county prior to issuance of a building permit. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 6) Sec. 18-98. - Buffer requirements. A 25-foot planted buffer, as defined by this section, shall be provided and maintained along any rear or side property line of adjacent properties of a poultry operation regulated by this article. No buffer shall extend within 15 feet of a public right-of-way line. Minimum buffer widths shall be established in accordance with the following schedule: When a building or structure used to house poultry or commercial livestock is constructed adjacent to a single-family residence, mobile/manufactured home, modular home or other dwelling, a 50-foot buffer along the entire portion of the property line abutting said dwelling, and such buffer shall also extend an additional 100 feet in each direction along said common property line to protect the yard and lot of the dwelling. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner of the poultry house operation to maintain existing vegetation within required buffers and to replant where sparsely vegetated. The vegetation shall be maintained as a continuous unbroken hedgerow for the entire period the property is used as a poultry farm. Dead or diseased foliage shall be replaced at the next appropriate planting time. The owner, operator or maintainer of a poultry farm shall use good husbandry techniques, such as pruning and fertilizing, to maintain maximum density and foliage. Vegetation planted for screening, except for ground covers, shall be installed after the site grading has been completed and of such type as to be a height of not less than three feet when planted and which will, in normal growth, attain a height of six feet within three years; provided, however that such plant materials can form a hardy screen, dense enough and high enough both to interrupt vision and to reduce the transmission of sound. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 7) Sec. 18-99. - Site plan. Prior to receiving a building permit, the developer of poultry houses shall include a plat of all land which the applicant proposes to place structures, improve or subdivide, including any unit divisions not scheduled for immediate development, and all land immediately adjacent extending 1,000 feet from the subject property, or of that directly opposite the subject property, extending 1,000 feet from the street frontage of opposite land, with the names of owners as shown in the assessor's files. Site plan must also clearly show all setbacks required of this article and include the proposed vegetative buffer. Developer must also include the truck routing plan with GA DOT approval. (Ord. of 2-13-2018, § 8)

div.head: Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; franchises for solid waste collection, § 74-26 et seq.; taxation, ch. 78.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - Fortunetelling, similar businesses prohibited. The practice of fortunetelling, phrenology, astrology, clairvoyance, palmistry or other kindred practices, businesses or professions, where a charge is made or a donation accepted for such services, and where such practice is carried on in the county outside the corporate limits of a municipality, is prohibited. (Res. of 2-10-1975) State Law reference— Authority to prohibit, regulate or tax fortunetelling, astrology and palmistry, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-15. Secs. 22-2—22-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAXES AND REGULATORY FEES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Business and occupational taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
Secs. 22-31—22-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PRIVATE TRESPASS TOWING DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 22-61. - Findings. The board of commissioners hereby finds and declares that: (a) A number of different businesses currently tow vehicles from private property at the request of the property owner, and without the prior consent or authorization of the owner or operator of the vehicle; (b) These different towing companies charge different rates, subject to different terms and conditions; (c) These companies are currently subject to regulation by the Georgia Department of Motor Vehicles, but are not subject to any local regulatory control; and (d) Regulating private trespass towing within the unincorporated areas of the Hart County, Georgia, would be a benefit to the citizens and other effected parties. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-62. - Definitions. As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following respective meanings: Attendant shall mean and refer to any person who is authorized by the impoundment facility to release a vehicle from the facility when presented with proper documentation of ownership and payment of appropriate fees. Department shall mean and refer to the Georgia Department of Motor Vehicle Safety, or any successor, department or agency responsible for regulating towing of trespassing vehicles on private property. Maximum rate tariff shall mean and refer to the publication containing the maximum rates as prescribed by the department that a wrecker company can assess for the towing and storage of vehicles removed pursuant to the authority granted in the nonconsensual towing permit. Nonconsensual towing carrier shall mean and refer to a wrecker service engaged in the towing of trespassing vehicles on private property without prior consent or authorization of the owner or operator of the vehicle and having a secure impoundment facility. Nonconsensual towing permit shall mean and refer to a permit issued by the department authorizing removal of improperly parked vehicles and trespassing personal property from private property. Nonconsensual towing shall mean and refer to towing without the prior consent or authorization of the owner or operator of the motor vehicle being towed. Normal business hours shall mean and refer to operating hours of nonconsensual towing carrier as approved by the department. Person shall mean and refer to any natural person, corporation, partnership, limited partnership, limited liability company, limited liability limited partnership or other type of entity. Receipt shall mean and refer to a document issued by the attendant to the owner of the vehicle stating all charges have been paid for the towing and storage of vehicle. Secure impoundment facility shall mean and refer to a facility owned or leased by a towing company for the purposes of providing secure storage of towed vehicles. Wrecker shall mean and refer to an automotive vehicle with hoisting apparatus and equipment for towing vehicles. The term wrecker also includes any vehicle otherwise equipped and used for the purposes of towing vehicles. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURES
Sec. 22-63. - Permit required. No person shall engage in any nonconsensual towing from or on any location in the unincorporated areas of Hart County, Georgia, without first obtaining a nonconsensual towing permit issued under the terms and conditions of this article. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-64. - Permit application. An applicant for a nonconsensual towing permit under the provisions of this article shall file with the county administrator or his or her designee a written application on a form provided for that purpose which shall be signed by the applicant, who shall be the owner of the business sought to be licensed. In addition to such other information as the county administrator deems appropriate, the following information shall be required in the application: (1) Name, address and telephone number of the applicant, including the trade name by which applicant does business and the street address of the premises, and if incorporated, the name registered with the secretary of state; (2) Name, address and telephone number of the nonconsensual towing carrier to be permitted; (3) Whether a previous license of applicant, or if applicable, corporate officer of applicant, under this article, has been revoked within two years of filing of the application; and (4) A statement that all the facts contained in the application are true. The county administrator shall prepare the form of the application, and may request such other information as the county administrator deems appropriate. The application shall be sworn under oath. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-65. - Permit fees. (a) The fee for the issuance of a nonconsensual towing permit shall be $50.00. The fee shall be charged when the nonconsensual towing permit is originally issued, and shall also be charged each year when a nonconsensual towing permit is renewed. (b) The fee for issuing a replacement nonconsensual towing permit for a lost, destroyed or mutilated nonconsensual towing permit is $25.00. (c) The fees for a nonconsensual towing permit granted in the second-half of the licensing year shall be reduced by one-half from the fee required by subsection (a) of this section. No other proration or reduction shall be allowed, regardless of the date on which application for such permit is filed or submitted. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-66. - Form of permit. A nonconsensual towing permit issued under this article shall be in such form as the county administrator shall determine. The nonconsensual towing permit shall bear the name and address of the permittee, the term of the permit, and a permit number. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-67. - Display of permit. A nonconsensual towing permit issued under this article, or a copy thereof, shall be kept in the wrecker which conducts any nonconsensual towing within the unincorporated areas of Hart County, and shall be available for review by any law enforcement officer or other county official upon request. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-68. - Refusal to issue or renew permit. The county administrator shall refuse to approve the issuance or renewal of a nonconsensual towing permit for any one or more of the following reasons: (1) A false statement as to a material fact or matter made in an application for a permit. (2) Revocation of a permit, pursuant to this article, of the applicant or corporate officer of the applicant within two years preceding the filing of the application. (3) The applicant for such permit has, within the past ten years, been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude. (4) The failure to comply with any provision of this article by the applicant, permittee, or any employee or agent of such applicant or permittee. (5) Any license or permit issued to the permittee by the department or any other municipality or local government is revoked or suspended. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-69. - Effect of indebtedness to county on permit. The county administrator or his or her designee shall not issue or renew a nonconsensual towing permit under this article and shall suspend or cancel a nonconsensual towing permit if it is determined that the applicant or permittee is indebted to the county of any fee, cost, penalty, or delinquent tax. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-70. - Replacement of permit. A replacement nonconsensual towing permit may be used for a lost, destroyed, or mutilated nonconsensual towing permit upon application on a form provided by the county administrator. A replacement nonconsensual towing permit shall have the word "REPLACEMENT" stamped across its face and shall bear the same number as the one it replaces. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-71. - Transferability of permit. A nonconsensual towing permit issued under the provisions of this article shall not be assignable or transferable. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-72. - Revocation and cancellation of permit. (a) If any person who owns, operates, manages, or controls any nonconsensual towing business in the unincorporated areas of Hart County shall violate any provision of this article, the county administrator shall have the power and authority to revoke and cancel all nonconsensual towing permits issued hereunder to such person by giving written notice to such person, to the address set forth on the application, stating the reason justifying such revocation and cancellation, and such nonconsensual towing permits shall be revoked and canceled ten days from such date of notice. (b) After a nonconsensual towing permit of a person has been revoked and canceled, no permit shall be issued to that person, or a corporation, partnership, limited liability company or other entity with which such person is affiliated, within a period of one year form the date of such revocation and cancellation, except at the discretion of the board of commissioners. If the permit of a person owning or operating a towing business in the unincorporated areas of Hart County is revoked and canceled, such person shall not be permitted to own, operate, manage or control a towing business until a new permit is granted. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-73. - Appeal from refusal to issue or renew permit or revocation and cancellation of permit. (a) If the county administrator refuses to approve the issuance of a nonconsensual towing permit or the renewal of a nonconsensual towing permit to an applicant or permittee, or revokes and cancels a nonconsensual towing permit, the county administrator shall notify the applicant or permittee in writing, and such action shall be final unless the applicant or permittee, within ten days of the receipt of such written notice, files a written appeal with the chief magistrate, who shall, within 30 days after the appeal is filed, consider all the evidence in support of or against the action appealed, and render a decision, either sustaining or reversing the action. (b) If the chief magistrate sustains the action of the county administrator, the applicant or permittee may, within ten days of that decision, file with the clerk of the board of commissioners a written appeal to the board of commissioners setting forth specific grounds for the appeal. The board of commissioners shall, within 60 days, grant a hearing to consider the action. The board of commissioners has authority to sustain, reverse, or modify the action appealed. The decision of the board of commissioners shall be final. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-74. - Responsibility of permittee. The permittee hereunder shall not violate any provision of this article, or permit any employee or agent of such permittee to permit a violation of this article with respect to any nonconsensual towing conducted within the unincorporated areas of Hart County. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) DIVISION 3. - SUBSTANTIVE REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 22-75. - Office requirements. A nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain an office with normal business hours and a listed public business telephone number. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-76. - Access to towed vehicles. A nonconsensual towing carrier shall provide reasonable access to any towed vehicle six days per week. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-77. - Proof of registration of wrecker. (a) A nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain proof of registration for each wrecker with the department. (b) A nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain a department cab card with current year's identification stamp for intrastate carriers, or appropriate registration receipt for interstate carriers in the cab of each wrecker. (c) Each vehicle operating under authority of a nonconsensual towing permit shall carry a copy of the permit in the cab of the vehicle. The copy shall be presented to any law enforcement upon request. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-78. - Compliance with safety regulations, etc. A nonconsensual towing carrier shall comply with the department's safety rules and regulations and the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-79. - Personnel records. A nonconsensual towing carrier must maintain and provide to the county administrator upon request, a list of all personnel operating wrecker equipment, as well as a current motor vehicle report on each driver. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-80. - Driver's licenses. Drivers must maintain a valid driver's license of the appropriate class and with the appropriate endorsements required to operate the nonconsensual towing carrier's vehicles under Georgia law. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-81. - Written contracts with property owners. It shall be unlawful for a nonconsensual towing carrier to engage in removal of vehicles without an authorized written contract, in the form prescribed by the department, signed by (1) the owner or other authorized agent for the owner of the real estate from which vehicles are to be towed and (2) an authorized agent of the nonconsensual towing carrier. A copy of the contract shall be made available, upon request, to officials and representatives of the county. The contract shall contain the name, address and phone number of the nonconsensual towing carrier, and the location of the impoundment facility, hours of operation, and the cost for removal of the vehicle and the charges for storage of the towed vehicle. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-82. - Equipment. All wreckers utilized by the wrecker companies for nonconsensual towing shall be equipped with the following: (1) Valid registration tag; (2) Fire extinguisher; and (3) Tow away lamps (tail, stop and turn signal lights for vehicles being towed). (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-83. - Decals. (a) The name, city and telephone number of the nonconsensual towing carrier shall be permanently affixed to both sides of any wrecker utilized by the nonconsensual towing carrier for nonconsensual towing. Letters shall be of sufficient size and form as to be readable at a distance of 50 feet while the wrecker is stationary. (b) A Georgia DOT number shall be affixed to the outside of the wrecker if the wrecker is operating within Georgia only. (c) If a nonconsensual towing carrier transports vehicles across state lines (interstate) a USDOT number or United State Motor Carrier (MC) number shall be affixed to the outside of the wrecker. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-84. - Maximum fees. (a) Any wrecker service engaged in the business of providing nonconsensual towing shall not charge the owner or operator of any towed motor vehicle more than the maximum rates published in the "nonconsensual towing maximum rate tariff" prescribed by the department. The fees stated in the maximum rate tariff shall be all inclusive; no additional fees may be charged for the use of dollies, trailers, lifts, slim jims or any other equipment or service. Additional charges will apply only when the vehicle(s) being towed weighs in excess of 26,000 GWVR. (b) No storage fees shall be charged for the first 24-hour period beginning with the time the motor vehicle is removed from the property. (c) The fees stated in subsection (a) shall be payable by cash, commonly recognized travelers checks, money orders, certified checks or cashier's checks at no additional charge. (d) No additional charges shall be assessed for storage of the vehicle once the vehicle has been claimed and payment is tendered to the towing company in the amount specified on the receipt and the vehicle has been removed from the impoundment facility. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-85. - Sign specifications; exclusion. (a) Owners of private property shall be required to place signs at each designated entrance to a parking lot or parking area from which the owner intends to tow vehicles without the consent of the owner or operator of such vehicle. Where there is no designated entrance, such signs shall be posted so as to be clearly visible from each and every parking space. Such signs shall be a minimum of 12 inches by 18 inches with a minimum of three-quarter-inch lettering. The wording "Private Parking" shall be printed in bold with a minimum of one-half-inch lettering. (b) Such signs located at a designated entrance to a parking lot shall be at least four feet above the site grade. Where there is no designated entrance, such signs shall be six feet above site grade. Posted signs must be free of any natural or manmade interference and be clearly visible. (c) Such signs shall also include the following language: (1) A warning that unauthorized vehicles will be towed; (2) Towing company name, address, and telephone number location; (3) Towing fees and daily storage fees; (4) Hours of operation; and (5) Method of payment. (d) No vehicle shall be relocated from private property which does not, at the time of the tow and for at least 24 hours prior thereto, have signs posted in accordance with the provisions of subsections (1) through (3) above. (e) All signs must be removed from private property within 15 days after the termination of the contract; or authorization from the property owner, or agent is withdrawn. (f) Notwithstanding the foregoing, the provisions of this Code section shall not apply to an owner of private residential property containing not more than four residential units. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-86. - Authorized attendant. (a) An attendant shall be available at the impoundment facility to provide reasonable access to any towed vehicle six days of each week. The attendant shall be available by phone 24 hours per day, seven days per week. (b) The attendant shall have the authority to release any impounded vehicle upon the owner meeting the legal requirements for release. (c) A nonconsensual towing carrier shall provide to the county a current telephone number of the attendant or other person responsible for releasing towed vehicles. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-87. - Redemption of vehicle from impound; issuance of receipt. (a) Any person claiming a vehicle impounded under a nonconsensual towing permit shall produce evidence of such person's identity and ownership or right of possession and shall pay all towing charges and storage fees which shall have accrued with respect to that vehicle. No storage fees shall be charged for any days the secure impoundment facility is closed and the owner is unable to claim the vehicle. (b) The owner or owner's agent shall produce a valid driver's license plus an ignition key which operates the vehicle, or indicia of ownership, such as a certificate of title, a valid and current registration card, bill of sale, or a lease or rental contract. (c) A receipt listing the specific charges for towing and storage of the vehicle shall be issued to the owner or agent claiming the vehicle and the attendant shall retain a copy of the receipt. The receipt shall be signed by the owner or agent claiming the vehicle and by the attendant. Such receipt shall identify the vehicle and shall become part of the nonconsensual towing carrier's records. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-88. - Records and reports. (a) Upon impoundment of any vehicle, the nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain records, which shall include the following information: Date and time of initial towing. Place of initial towing. Date and time of arrival at the impoundment lot. Date and time of release to the owner. Name of the towing company driver and helper. Cost for towing of the vehicle. Cost of storage of the vehicle. (b) The records shall be maintained at a location where any county official or representative may review such records in person during normal business hours. (c) All records required by these rules shall be preserved for a period of three years, unless otherwise specified by the county. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-89. - Secure impoundment facility. (a) A nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain a secure impoundment facility for towed vehicles at a location which is no more than ten miles from the Hart County Courthouse. (b) A nonconsensual towing carrier shall provide for effective and efficient security for the secure impoundment facility at all times. The secure impoundment facility shall be fenced with a minimum of six feet fencing, lighted, and equipped with a lock or enclosed building. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-90. - Insurance requirements. (a) A nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain the minimum liability insurance prescribed by the department and the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration on all vehicles used in its business as follows: (1) For wreckers with an origin and destination wholly within the State of Georgia (interstate), the nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain public liability and property damage insurance with the following limits: (i) $100,000.00 limit for bodily injury to or death of one person; (ii) $300,000.00 limit for bodily injuries to or death of total persons in one accident; and (iii) $50,000.00 loss or damage in any one accident to property of others. (2) For wreckers with an origin and destination outside the State of Georgia (interstate), the nonconsensual towing carrier shall maintain public liability and property damage insurance with the following limits: (i) $750,000.00 liability; (ii) MCS-90 (proof of liability insurance). (b) Liability insurance, which covers stored vehicles and contents, shall be maintained on the storage lot(s) sufficient to cover the actual value of all stored vehicles. The minimum amount of liability insurance for coverage of the storage vehicles shall be at least $25,000.00. (c) A copy of the certificates of insurance shall be furnished to the county on an annual basis. A 30-day advance cancellation notice shall be provided prior to insurance cancellation. No lapse in insurance coverage will be allowed. (d) A nonconsensual towing permit issued by the county shall be in effect only while the nonconsensual towing carrier is in compliance with all requirements for filing proof of insurance. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Sec. 22-91. - Vehicle not towed upon operator returning. (a) The operator or driver employed by a nonconsensual towing carrier summoned to tow away any vehicle from private property shall not tow the vehicle away and shall not charge any fee if the operator or owner of the vehicle returns, and produces the ignition key to the vehicle, and immediately removes the vehicle from the private property. (b) If the vehicle has been hooked with hoisting apparatus or loaded by the nonconsensual towing carrier and the vehicle has not left the premises, an operator's fee as prescribed in the maximum rate tariff may apply. (c) Once the nonconsensual towing carrier has left the location to which it was summoned, charges may be assessed in accordance with the maximum rate tariff. The operator's fee, as described in subsection (b), shall not apply in this instance. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) DIVISION 4. - PENALTIES
Sec. 22-92. - Civil penalties. The county administrator is authorized to impose a civil penalty for a violation of any provision of this article in an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 for each violation. (Ord. No. 308-2005, § 1, 11-17-05) Sec. 22-93. - Criminal penalties. Any violation of any provision of this article shall be punishable in accordance with section 1-13 of this Code, in addition to the imposition of any civil penalty, if applicable. (Ord. of 3-8-2005, § 1) Secs. 22-94—22-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PRIVATELY OWNED LANDFILL
Sec. 22-116. - Definitions. Terms as used herein shall be as defined and set forth in the Hart County Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan and as defined and set forth by the Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act O.G.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. (Ord. of 10-26-2004, § 1) Sec. 22-117. - Standards. (a) No person, firm or corporation shall commence or continue the operation of a landfill for the disposal of solid waste except upon payment of the fee prescribed herein, the issuance of a license, and/or that license continued in force, and upon compliance with the terms and conditions set forth herein. (b) Privately owned inert waste landfills and other landfills or dumps shall meet waste reduction goals of the Hart County Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan. (c) The operator shall have obtained and shall maintain in force valid permits from the appropriate federal and state regulatory agencies. (d) The landfill shall be operated at all times in full compliance with the terms of any permit from regulatory agencies, and all applicable federal state and county laws and regulations, as amended. In the event of a conflict between this article and other laws or regulations, the most stringent shall apply. (e) The county or its designee shall have the right to inspect the landfill at its discretion to insure that said site complies with the laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of Hart County and the State of Georgia. (f) The landfill shall be operated in an efficient and workmanlike manner and in such fashion that it does not constitute a nuisance to others. The facility shall be operated so as to prevent air, land or water pollution, or public health hazards. (g) The landfill operator shall allow to be placed in the landfill only those materials which are authorized by appropriate permits. Specifically, and without limiting the foregoing, there shall be no disposition in any landfill of solid waste or of nonsolid waste which would be classified as "hazardous" material. (h) Liquid or nonsolid waste shall not be disposed of in a landfill. (i) The operator of a landfill shall obtain and maintain in force throughout the period of time that the operator holds a license for the landfill a performance bond with good and sufficient security payable to the county in the penal amount of $50,000.00 per acre of landfill permitted and conditioned upon compliance by the operator of the landfill with federal and state law and county ordinances respecting the operations of landfills. The requirement for furnishing good and sufficient security shall be deemed to have been satisfied if: (1) The bond which is furnished is secured by a corporate surety engaged in that business and authorized to do business in the state; (2) The bond is accompanied by the deposit in a federally insured bank in the sum of $50,000.00 per acre of landfill permitted evidenced by a certificate of deposit issued jointly in the name of the principal and the county; or (3) The bond is accompanied by a letter of credit from a federally-insured bank in the amount of $50,000.00 per acre of landfill permitted. If a cash deposit is made and certificate of deposit issued, the terms of the deposit shall be such that the principal may not withdraw the amount so long as the principal is engaged in the landfill business in the county without the consent of the county, but may be drawn against by the county at any time upon presentation of a resolution of the board that the sum to be withdrawn has been determined by the board to be necessary to cure a breach of the bond. Until otherwise ordered by the board, interest on a bond shall be paid to the other joint owner. If a letter of credit is furnished, the county shall be entitled to draw upon the letter of credit in the same manner as it might draw upon a cash deposit. In the event of cancellation or withdrawal of the letter of credit, the license of the principal to conduct a landfill operation shall automatically be suspended, and such operation shall cease immediately. (j) The operator of the landfill shall obtain and maintain in force at all times a general public liability policy which will insure against injury or death to persons and injury or damage to property in the amounts, respectively, of $1,000,000.00 and $500,000.00, and said policy shall provide for 30 days prior notice of cancellation to be made in writing to the county. (k) The operator of the landfill shall maintain records which will reflect, at a minimum, the date and hour of the deposit of each load of solid waste, the name and address of the owner of the truck in which the waste was delivered, and a general description of the waste which is deposited. The operator of the landfill shall file in the office of the county administrator a copy of such records by the tenth day of the following month reflecting landfill operations for the preceding calendar month. The landfill operator shall likewise furnish such other and further information to the county administrator as he may require in order to verify the actual landfill operation. (l) Every operator shall make the landfill and the records maintained in connection therewith available for inspection at reasonable times by the county administrator or other person designated by the governing authority of the county so as to enable the county to determine whether the landfill is being operated properly. (m) In addition to other remedies, if the county shall determine that a landfill is being operated in violation of the provisions hereof, the board may order the landfill closed or its operation suspended and in default of compliance with such order, the board may seek an injunction to restrain further operations either on a permanent basis or until violations hereof are corrected. (n) Landfill business hours shall commence no earlier than 6:00 a.m. and cease by 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. (o) Within 30 days of commencing solid waste handling activities, the operator will provide to the county a copy of the notice having been placed on the recorded property deed that the property will be used for landfilling operations. (p) Upon final closure, all deeds for real property which have been used for landfilling shall include notice of the landfill operations, the date the landfill operation commenced and terminated, an accurate legal description of the actual location of the landfill, and a description of the type of solid wastes which have been deposited in the landfill. The owner or operator must, concurrently with the submission of notice of final closure, submit to the county confirmation that the information required in this section has been recorded on the property deed(s). Said notice of final closure must be provided to the county within 30 days of receiving the final load of waste, and shall confirm the date of final wasted received and an accurate legal description of the boundaries of the landfill. (q) Any landfill site not receiving waste for a period in excess of 180 days shall be deemed abandoned and in violation of this article unless properly closed. (r) The operator shall be responsible for leveling the dumped material with appropriate grading equipment and obtaining maximum practical compaction. (s) Vehicles shall be allowed into a landfill site only if waste is covered to prevent the blowing of material from the vehicle, and all such vehicles shall maintain strict adherence with all department of transportation regulations regarding the cover on and of any vehicles coming into said landfill site. (t) All facilities shall have an operator in attendance at all times when the landfill is in use, and the landfill must be barricaded when closed to the public. (u) In addition to the residential buffer fence set forth below, all landfills shall be enclosed with a security fence at least six feet in height with openings therein not more than those in two-inch mesh wire or some other similar fencing materials or device. Litter control fencing shall be adequate to prevent paper and similar or related refuse from blowing from the facility onto neighboring property. Rodent and insect infestation shall be adequately controlled by the operator. (v) Any changes in the normal drainage of the property upon which the facility is located shall be accommodated by storm sewers, or other appropriate devices installed at the expense of the operator, as necessary to properly provide for adequate drainage. (w) Operators must pack and cover all materials placed thereon with at least one foot of earth in such a manner as to prevent fires and meet any and all other requirements of fire code. This cover shall be required at least monthly or at whatever interval is required by the Georgia Environmental Protection Division incidental to its approval of the site. All completed landfills must be covered with at least two feet of earth. Scavenging and burning of any kind of refuse on the fill is prohibited. All landfills shall have and keep on their premises, in good working order, adequate equipment to comply with the requirements set forth in this article. (x) Access: (1) Access from paved public roads shall be required. All such roads shall meet the standards for paved roads set forth in the Hart County Code of Ordinances. (2) The operator of a landfill is required to submit an impact study prepared by a registered engineer, which shall address the following: a. Traffic counts identifying peak morning, afternoon and evening traffic; b. A determination of the present level of capacity and location and amount of excess capacities of local roadways; c. Projected estimates of trips to be generated by proposed development for present and future traffic; and d. Show impact of the proposed landfill upon road system abutting the landfill property and recommend improvements to the physical layout of said roadways for safe and efficient traffic operation. 1. Truck traffic routes and entrances to the facility must be reviewed and approved by the county, and if applicable, the state department of transportation. 2. If the proposed landfill is accessed from a county road, the operator shall be responsible for improving the county road to accommodate the increased traffic and loads; said improvements are to be determined and approved by the county. 3. Access shall not be allowed through any residential subdivision or residential development. 4. Access to the landfill site shall be limited to authorized entrances, which shall be closed when the site is not in operation. 5. It shall be the responsibility of the operator to keep all access roads to the site clean and free of litter and debris. (l) Buffer: For the purposes of this section, distance shall be by airline measurement from the property line, using the closest property lines The required buffer shall be: (1) A minimum of 300-foot wide buffer is required adjacent to any property line containing a residential use. Further, a minimum six-foot high solid fence/wall shall be required inside buffers adjacent to any property line containing a residential use. A minimum of a 500-foot wide buffer is required to any residence. (2) A minimum 50-foot wide buffer is required adjacent to public rights-of-way. (3) A minimum 1,000-foot buffer is required from the location of any well used for drinking water. (4) A minimum 3,000-foot wide buffer is required adjacent to any property line upon which a church, school, government building, library, civic center, public park or playground is located. (5) A minimum 5,280 feet (one mile) distance is required from any parcel of land with the same or similar use. (6) A minimum of 5,280 feet (one mile) distance, or any additional distance promulgated by the environmental protection division, is required from the USACE line of Lake Hartwell, the Savannah River, or any tributaries thereto. (7) No landfill may be located over any "significant ground water recharge areas" of Hart County as shown on Map 5-5, attached hereto, and a minimum of 1,000 feet distance, or any additional distance promulgated by the environmental protection division, is required from any such delineated area. (z) Inert landfills: (1) A uniform compacted layer of cover material no less than one foot in depth shall be placed over all exposed inert waste material at least monthly. (2) The landfill site shall be graded and drained to minimize runoff onto the landfill surface and to prevent erosion and to drain water from the surface of the landfill. (3) Appropriate means shall be provided to prevent and control fires. Stockpiled soil is considered to be the most satisfactory fire fighting material. (4) A uniform compacted layer of final cover not less than two feet in depth, and a vegetative cover shall be placed over the final lift not later than one month following final placement of inert waste within that lift. (5) An inert landfill shall not exceed ten acres. a. Sanitary landfills: The minimum parcel of contiguous land for a sanitary landfill shall be 25 acres, and shall not exceed 100 acres. (Ord. of 10-26-2004, § 2) Sec. 22-118. - Requirements for license issuance. (a) Each applicant shall apply to the county clerk for the license required by this article by sworn statement that all of the requirements of this article have been met, and shall specifically set forth exactly how each such requirement was met. (b) Attached to each such application shall be the following: (1) Evidence of valid permits from the appropriate federal and state regulatory agencies approving the use of said property as a privately owned landfill.
